docs.snippet: FOR almost three years, Walter Biggs and his wife, Clara Rubio, searched in Manhattan for an apartment they could afford. After scouring scores of two-bedroom apartments packed into 650 square feet and priced at almost half a million dollars, they...
docs.lead_paragraph: FOR almost three years, Walter Biggs and his wife, Clara Rubio, searched in Manhattan for an apartment they could afford. After scouring scores of two-bedroom apartments packed into 650 square feet and priced at almost half a million dollars, they were ready to give up when a friend suggested they look in Harlem. That afternoon, Mr. Biggs drove north from their home in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and spent several hours admiring West Harlem's brownstones and Hudson River views. When he got home, he told Ms. Rubio, ''We're moving to Harlem.''
docs.abstract: If You're Thinking of Living In column profiles West Harlem in upper Manhattan as place to live; photos; map (M)

headline.main: If You're Thinking of Living In/West Harlem; Brownstones in Manhattan, at a Discount

docs.snippet: ''Have fun, Dad,'' called one of Clive Davis's sons, as his father approached the red carpet outside the Beverly Hills Hotel. Mr. Davis, who has been the host of this pre-Grammy gala since 1974, when he founded Arista Records, waved.     The party...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''Have fun, Dad,'' called one of Clive Davis's sons, as his father approached the red carpet outside the Beverly Hills Hotel. Mr. Davis, who has been the host of this pre-Grammy gala since 1974, when he founded Arista Records, waved. The party, a sit-down dinner for 600, followed by a concert of artists from all labels, is known as the Grammy equivalent of the legendary Swifty Lazar Oscar bash. And this year's celebration had a special resonance for Mr. Davis, 67, who is known mostly for his successes with radio-friendly, schmaltzy pop hits like Barry Manilow's ''Mandy'' and Whitney Houston's ''I Will Always Love You,'' and for his longevity in a business known for burnout. Mr. Davis operates like a politician; lots of glad-handing up front while he controls business out of earshot.
docs.abstract: A Night Out With profile of Clive Davis, who has hosted pre-Grammy gala since he founded Arista Records in 1974; interview; photo (M)

headline.main: A NIGHT OUT WITH/Clive Davis; A Rock Angel Refuses to Fall

docs.snippet: Robert Enrico, a popular French movie director whose memorable 24-minute film, ''Incident at Owl Creek,'' won a Palme d'Or at the 1962 Cannes International Film Festival as well as an Oscar for best short film at the 1964 Academy Awards, died on F...
docs.lead_paragraph: Robert Enrico, a popular French movie director whose memorable 24-minute film, ''Incident at Owl Creek,'' won a Palme d'Or at the 1962 Cannes International Film Festival as well as an Oscar for best short film at the 1964 Academy Awards, died on Friday. He was 69. The cause was cancer, his agent said.
docs.abstract: Robert Enrico, French movie director, dies at age 69 (M)

docs.snippet: The Paris taxi driver was of the chatty kind that makes you cringe as you try not to shut your cream coat in the door. As we crawled down Avenue Montaigne, he waved expansively at the hulking house of Christian Dior.    ''They've got a new designe...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Paris taxi driver was of the chatty kind that makes you cringe as you try not to shut your cream coat in the door. As we crawled down Avenue Montaigne, he waved expansively at the hulking house of Christian Dior. ''They've got a new designer,'' he said knowingly. ''He and his friends were in my car last night. He looked like a Mohican, but he said he came from London and they are all crazy over there.''
docs.abstract: Comment by Suzy Menkes, fashion editor of International Herald Tribune, on how she got some of her greatest scoops; drawings (special section, Fashions of The Times) (part 2 of 2-part section) (S)

headline.main: Inside Trading; How I Got That Scoop!

docs.snippet: At first they blamed winter vacation. Then they wondered whether another fire had struck. Some even believed that the Muslim holiday Ramadan had played a part. Finally, when no one could explain why the newsstand in the north corner of Grand Army ...
docs.lead_paragraph: At first they blamed winter vacation. Then they wondered whether another fire had struck. Some even believed that the Muslim holiday Ramadan had played a part. Finally, when no one could explain why the newsstand in the north corner of Grand Army Plaza was closed, neighbors began thinking conspiracy. Commuters who bumbled out of their doors early in the morning on their way to the Nos. 2 and 3 trains lamented the newsstand's absence. No matter their state of mind, they knew they could count on it for a newspaper or a magazine for their bleary-eyed ride to work. The brothers who own the newsstand, Zoeb and Mohamed Mithaiwala, also sold coffee and candy.
docs.abstract: New York City Parks Comr Henry Stern says newsstand on corner of Brooklyn's Grand Army Plaza has been closed because owners, brothers Zoeb and Mohamed Mithaiwala, failed to pay final installment, $105,000 of five-year contract; photo (M)

headline.main: A Newsstand Dies, and With It, a Neighborhood's Hub

docs.snippet: THE American photographer F. Holland Day (1864-1933) spent much of the last 15 years of his life in his family home in Norwood, Mass., not far from here. He had long since stopped making pictures. He was all but forgotten by the art world. After h...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE American photographer F. Holland Day (1864-1933) spent much of the last 15 years of his life in his family home in Norwood, Mass., not far from here. He had long since stopped making pictures. He was all but forgotten by the art world. After his mother's death, he took to his bed and had it surrounded by bookcases, their contents an arm's length away. They enclosed him like a protective box, a live-in camera lucida. In fact, Day has never altogether faded from view. He figures as a pioneer in any history of American photography. And, with his homoerotic allegorical tableaus and his self-portraits as Jesus, he's just too ''out there'' to go unnoticed. At the same time, his work has been hard to see. The last comprehensive career survey was nearly a century ago.
docs.abstract: Holland Cotter profiles American photographer F Holland Day (1864-1933), describing him as pioneer; discusses exhibition Art and the Camera: The Photographs of F Holland Day, on view at Museum of Fine Arts in Boston; photos (L)

headline.main: A Photography Pioneer, Semi-Obscure No More

docs.snippet: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.    BARBEZ, GROOVELILY, Tonic, 107 Norfolk Street, near Delancey Street, Lower...
docs.lead_paragraph: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert. BARBEZ, GROOVELILY, Tonic, 107 Norfolk Street, near Delancey Street, Lower East Side, (212) 358-7503. Barbez is a Brooklyn-based collective that considers cafe decadence from a European standpoint, inspired by fruitful sources like Kurt Weill and Édith Piaf. Groovelily features Valerie Vigoda, who has sung and played her magic violin with stars like Cyndi Lauper and Cher. Sunday at 8 p.m.; admission is $10 (Ann Powers).

docs.snippet: GRASSO-Thomas A. Age 54. Died February 10, 2001. Teacher, actor, administrator. Director of Herbert Berghof Studio. Former associate at Actors Connection. Mr. Grasso taught multiply-handicapped children at the New York Institute for the Blind. He ...
docs.lead_paragraph: GRASSO-Thomas A. Age 54. Died February 10, 2001. Teacher, actor, administrator. Director of Herbert Berghof Studio. Former associate at Actors Connection. Mr. Grasso taught multiply-handicapped children at the New York Institute for the Blind. He was a member/performer with the Village Light Opera Group, et al. Beloved son, brother and uncle; devoted partner; friend to animals. Survived by his life partner, David T. Jones; parents Anthony & Mary Grasso of N. Arlington, NJ; sister Judith McLaughlin and husband Thomas; sister Regina Purcell and children Angelica and Vincent; brother Anthony Grasso and wife Robin; and Oscar, his cat. A memorial service will be announced. Donations in Mr. Grasso's name may be made to: HB Playwrights Foundation, 122 Bank Street, NYC 10014.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRASSO, THOMAS A.

docs.snippet: After months of ignoring allegations that the police routinely harassed women and tried to intimidate critics, the Wallkill Town Board approved an agreement tonight with the state attorney general's office providing for strict guidelines on police...
docs.lead_paragraph: After months of ignoring allegations that the police routinely harassed women and tried to intimidate critics, the Wallkill Town Board approved an agreement tonight with the state attorney general's office providing for strict guidelines on police conduct and oversight by a federal monitor. The attorney general, Eliot L. Spitzer, said the 31-page agreement, known as a consent decree, was ''precisely the same document'' his office had offered to the Town Board before his office filed a federal civil rights complaint against the town in mid-January. The agreement settles the complaint.
docs.abstract: Wallkill (NY) Town Board, after months of ignoring allegations that police routinely harassed women and tried to intimidate critics, approves agreement with New York State Attorney General's Office providing for strict guidelines on police conduct and oversight by federal monitor (M)

headline.main: Town Agrees To Restrain Police Force
